extendedMetadata.name: Objective
extendedMetadata.value: L.O. 7.3: Apply symbolic-interaction theories to the topic of deviance.

subject: Sociology
metadata.title: CE.07.17 Defining Deviance Symbolic Interaction Theories Apply L.O. 7.3

body.description: CE.07.17, Defining Deviance: Symbolic-Interaction Theories, Apply, L.O. 7.3

containerConfig.description: CE.07.17, Defining Deviance: Symbolic-Interaction Theories, Apply, L.O. 7.3

config.question: Which of the following is an example of secondary deviance?

choices.content: Jake sees his high school friends drinking at a party and joins in. Driving home, he crashes his car into a tree and vows never to drink again.

Elliot is an honor student at school. After he is caught using recreational drugs by his father, he stops going to school, loses many of his friends, begins to take drugs every day, and is hostile toward members of his family.
Carol is 15, and most of her friends have children. She wants a child of her own and begins having unprotected sex with her boyfriend.
Sanjay was arrested for child molestation and spent 10 years in prison. Now that he is free, he has to register as a sex offender wherever he lives.

answer_3.response:
Consider this: Primary deviance can lead to secondary deviance. What is an example of primary deviance?
Refer to Learning Objective 7.3: Apply symbolic-interaction theories to the topic of deviance.
